fixed_design: compute sample size/power of a fixed design

Yujie Zhao

Source: vignettes/articles/usage-fixed-design.Rmd
usage-fixed-design.Rmd
library(tibble)
library(gt)
library(gsDesign)
library(gsDesign2)

Introduction

In this vignette, we introduce the key functionality of fixed_design() in gsDesign2. Generally speaking, fixed_design() is capable of both power calculations and sample size calculations under many methods, including

  • AHR
  • Fleming-Harrington (FH) (Farrington and Manning 1990)
  • Magirr-Burman (MB)
  • Lachin-Foulkes (LF) (Lachin and Foulkes 1986)
  • RMST (Yung and Liu 2020)
  • Milestone (Yung and Liu 2020)
  • Risk difference (RD) (Mehrotra and Railkar 2000).

Throughout this vignette, we assume the design parameter is

# Enrollment rate
enroll_rate <- define_enroll_rate(
  duration = 18,
  rate = 20
)

# Failure rates
fail_rate <- tibble::tibble(
  stratum = "All",
  duration = c(4, 100),
  fail_rate = log(2) / 12,
  hr = c(1, .6),
  dropout_rate = .001
)

# Study duration in months
study_duration <- 36

# Experimental / Control randomization ratio
ratio <- 1

# 1-sided Type I error
alpha <- 0.025
# Type II error (1 - power)
beta <- 0.1

Examples of AHR

If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

fixed_design(
  "ahr",
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version
Fixed Design under AHR Method1
Design N Event time Bound alpha Power design
Average hazard ratio 463.078 324.7077 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9 ahr
1 Power computed with average hazard ratio method.

Given the above enrollment rate and enrollment duration, one can calculate the power of AHR by

fixed_design(
  "ahr",
  alpha = alpha,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version
Fixed Design under AHR Method1
Design N Event time Bound alpha Power design
Average hazard ratio 360 252.43 36 1.959964 0.025 0.815886 ahr
1 Power computed with average hazard ratio method.

Examples of FH

If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

# Fixed design with a given power with default rho/gamma
fixed_design(
  "fh",
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version
## Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `design`.
## Unknown or uninitialised column: `design`.
Fixed Design under Fleming-Harrington Method1
Design N Event time Bound alpha Power design
Fleming-Harrington FH(0, 0.5) 355.5725 249.3255 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9 fh
1 Power for Fleming-Harrington test using method of Yung and Liu.

In the above example, the FH parameters (rho, gamma) take the default value as rho = 0, gamma = 0.5. But users can always custom their rho and gamma by

# Fixed design with a given power with input rho/gamma
fixed_design(
  "fh",
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio,
  rho = 0.5,
  gamma = 0.5
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version
## Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `design`.
## Unknown or uninitialised column: `design`.
Fixed Design under Fleming-Harrington Method1
Design N Event time Bound alpha Power design
Fleming-Harrington FH(0.5, 0.5) 376.0673 263.6963 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9 fh
1 Power for Fleming-Harrington test using method of Yung and Liu.

Given the above enrollment rate and enrollment duration, one can calculate the power of FH under the default rho, gamma by

# Fixed design with power calculated
fixed_design(
  "fh",
  alpha = alpha,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version
## Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `design`.
## Unknown or uninitialised column: `design`.
Fixed Design under Fleming-Harrington Method1
Design N Event time Bound alpha Power design
Fleming-Harrington FH(0, 0.5) 360 252.43 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9034347 fh
1 Power for Fleming-Harrington test using method of Yung and Liu.

But users can always custom their rho and gamma by

# Fixed design with power calculated
fixed_design(
  "fh",
  alpha = alpha,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio,
  rho = 0.5, gamma = 0.5
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Unknown or uninitialised column: `design`.
Fixed Design under Fleming-Harrington Method1
Design N Event time Bound alpha Power design
Fleming-Harrington FH(0.5, 0.5) 360 252.43 36 1.959964 0.025 0.8872751 fh
1 Power for Fleming-Harrington test using method of Yung and Liu.

Examples of mb

If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

fixed_design(
  "mb",
  ratio = ratio,
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version
## Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `design`.
Fixed Design under Magirr-Burman Method1
Design N Event time Bound alpha Power design
Modestly weighted LR: tau = 6 412.2826 289.0902 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9 mb
1 Power for computed with method of Yung and Liu.

In the above example, the mb parameter (tau) takes the default value as tau = 6. But users can always custom their tau by

fixed_design(
  "mb",
  ratio = ratio,
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  tau = 4
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## We will enforse the requirement from next version

Design N Event time Bound alpha Power design
Modestly weighted LR: tau = 4 429.7777 301.3577 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9 mb
1 Power for computed with method of Yung and Liu.

Given the above enrollment rate and enrollment duration, one can calculate the power of MB under the default tau = 6 by

fixed_design(
  "mb",
  ratio = ratio,
  alpha = alpha,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()

fixed_design(
  "lf",
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()

1 Power using Lachin and Foulkes method applied using expected average hazard ratio (AHR) at time of planned analysis.

fixed_design(
  "lf",
  alpha = alpha,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration

Examples of MaxCombo

If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

fixed_design(
  "maxcombo",
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version
## Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `design`.
## Unknown or uninitialised column: `design`.
Fixed Design under MaxCombo Method1
Design N Event time Bound alpha Power design
MaxCombo: logrank, FH(0, 0.5) 359.06 251.7709 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9 maxcombo
1 Power for MaxCombo test with Fleming-Harrington tests.

In the above example, the MaxCombo parameters take the default value

data.frame(rho = c(0, 0), gamma = c(0, 0.5), tau = -1) %>% gt()
rho gamma tau
0 0.0 -1
0 0.5 -1

But users can always custom their rho, gamma, tau by

fixed_design(
  "maxcombo",
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  rho = c(0, 0.5, 0.5),
  gamma = c(0, 0, 0.5),
  tau = c(-1, 4, 6)
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()

Examples of RMST

If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

fixed_design(
  "rmst",
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio,
  tau = 18
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
## Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `design`.
Fixed Design under Restricted Mean Survival Time Method1
Design N Event time Bound alpha Power design
RMST: tau = 18 1298.358 910.4017 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9 rmst
1 Power for computed with method of Yung and Liu.

Given the above enrollment rate and enrollment duration, one can calculate the power of RMST by

fixed_design(
  "rmst",
  alpha = alpha,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio,
  tau = 18
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
## Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `design`.
Fixed Design under Restricted Mean Survival Time Method1
Design N Event time Bound alpha Power design
RMST: tau = 18 360 252.43 36 1.959964 0.025 0.4001002 rmst
1 Power for computed with method of Yung and Liu.

Examples of Milestone

If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

fixed_design(
  "milestone",
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio,
  tau = 18
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
## Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `design`.
Fixed Design under Milestone Method1
Design N Event time Bound alpha Power design
Milestone: tau = 18 556.9044 390.4983 36 1.959964 0.025 0.9 milestone
1 Power for computed with method of Yung and Liu.

Given the above enrollment rate and enrollment duration, one can calculate the power of Milestone by

fixed_design(
  "milestone",
  alpha = alpha,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration,
  ratio = ratio,
  tau = 18
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
## Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `design`.
Fixed Design under Milestone Method1
Design N Event time Bound alpha Power design
Milestone: tau = 18 360 252.43 36 1.959964 0.025 0.7409392 milestone
1 Power for computed with method of Yung and Liu.

Examples of RD

If one wants to get a power of 90%, one can calculate the sample size by

fixed_design(
  "rd",
  alpha = alpha,
  power = 1 - beta,
  p_c = .15,
  p_e = .1,
  rd0 = 0,
  ratio = ratio
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
Fixed Design of Risk Difference under Farrington-Manning Method1
Design N Bound alpha Power design
Risk difference 1834.641 1.959964 0.025 0.9 rd
1 Risk difference power without continuity correction using method of Farrington and Manning.

Given the above enrollment rate and enrollment duration, one can calculate the power by

fixed_design(
  "rd",
  alpha = alpha,
  power = NULL,
  p_c = .15,
  p_e = .1,
  rd0 = 0,
  n = 2000,
  ratio = ratio
) %>%
  summary() %>%
  as_gt()
Fixed Design of Risk Difference under Farrington-Manning Method1
Design N Bound alpha Power design
Risk difference 2000 1.959964 0.025 0.9228823 rd
1 Risk difference power without continuity correction using method of Farrington and Manning.

Examples to get multiple designs together 

x_ahr <- fixed_design(
  "ahr",
  alpha = alpha,
  ratio = ratio,
  enroll_rate = enroll_rate,
  fail_rate = fail_rate,
  study_duration = study_duration
)
## Warning in check_fail_rate(fail_rate): Please use `define_fail_rate` to specify `fail_rate` argument.
## We will enforse the requirement from next version

  "milestone",

  study_duration = study_duration,
  tau = 30
)

rbind(
  summary(x_ahr), summary(x_fh),
  summary(x_mb), summary(x_lf),
  summary(x_maxcombo), summary(x_rmst),
  summary(x_milestone)
) %>% gt()
